cover.title: This Is Your Brain on Food

title.text: This Is Your Brain on Food

bookmarks.note: Vagus nerve stimulation enhances memory. So I can eat or activate my sex drive in such a way that it helps me remember
Norepinephrine enhances memory, especially during emotional times
A1 caseine protein in milk is bad for you: gastrointestinal inflammation, slower thinking, more errors on info processing test
Dairy and gluten (Celiac disease) intolerance both linked to exacerbating ADHD symptoms
Black pepper + turmeric to activate the turmeric

Turmeric (curcumin) + pinch black pepper

200mg Ginkgo bullova can help w/ anxiety, depression, PTSD

Vitamin E appears to help prevent brain damage
Sources: one tablespoon of wheat germ oil, sunflower seeds, dried roasted almonds, hazelnuts, peanut butter, broccoli, spinach, raw tomatoes
Free radicals can “cause stress“ in the brain

Farmed, fatty fish > wild fish
Just make sure this is actually scientifically based, and not politically motivated

Eat blueberries (1/2–1 cup per day)
Blueberry-enriched diet:
^ serotonin levels in the brain
Reduced free radicals (and inflammation)
Raised levels of SCAR-2 (decreased in PTSD patients and suicide victims)

Glutamic acid -> glutamate [-> MSG]
Sources (bad):
Seaweed, cheeses, soy sauce, tomatoes, high-protein foods (meats/seafood)

Sources (bad) of MSG/glutamates:
Fish/oyster/tomato sauce, Parmesan cheese, miso, chips, ready-to-eat meals, mushrooms, spinach
Tomato sauce = pizza :(
Low glutamate diet -> helps w/ lower PTSD [correlation]
Banana increases blood glucose more than an apple
Relisten to chapter 4 and include my notes. Like that thought I had about how she’s mentioning the noise study with those two chemicals you might want to add

Extracts of passionflower / guava and combinations of AAs (e.g. Lys/Arg) reduce anxiety.
PF increases GABA, decreasing anxiety, and doesn’t cause sedation.

Plavix is a blood thinner.
Plavix & MAOIs don’t do well with passionflower extract (90 mg per day)
Note: glass absorbs all ultraviolet B light/radiation, so light streaming in though the window doesn’t provide the vitamin D we need.

Vitamin D sources
Sun exposure, fortified milk, egg yolk, salmon, sun-dried mushrooms, cod liver oil

Note:
Vitamin D = neurosteroid
Decreases inflammation & toxic destruction of cells
Controls release of nerve growth factor -> hypocampal (HPA :. Anxiety) + cortical neurons
Vitamin D pill every two weeks, for women with Vit D deficiency and diabetes, helped reduce anxiety

Chickpeas = tryptophan
Whole wheat pita bread provides carbs to (probably) help increase trp absorption from hummus
Our avocado hummus on whole grain toast (for breakfast)

Trp (purified) = serotonin precursor
But W isn’t prioritized by the body. So you actually have to absorb it properly

Plain yogurt with active cultures, kimchi
Improve cognitive faculties, e.g. memory, and slow cognitive decline. Mechanism not yet known.
Vegetable oil -> canola oil
Omega-3 (icosapentanoic acid) -> less anxiety, less stress (measured by IL-6)

Brain inflammation -> anxiety
Fiber decreases inflammation
Beans, brown rice, berries, bran, baked potato (w/ skin on)
Pears, apples, bananas, almonds, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, carrots, walnuts, oats, buckwheat, pearl barley, etc.
Plus you eat fiber more slowly

Anxiety, foods to add: dietary fiber
Note: if it can be broken down by bacteria, fiber is called “fermentable dietary fiber”—promotes growth of good gut bacteria (e.g. pivitobacterium? and lactobacillus increase, alleviating anxiety)
Celiac disease: gluten causes… anxiety? Pain?

Heavy drinkers
Men: 14/wk, or 4 times once per month
Women: 7/wk, or 3
Note: social anxiety disorder > quadruples risk of alcohol use disorder
Anxious people who drink regularly sleep more poorly
Morning after, mild to moderate alcohol withdrawal: guilty, jittery, jumping out of skin

Starbucks Venti = 475mg
Nespresso capsule: 1oz coffee w/ only 50–80mg

Effect on anxiety
<100mg: no effect
100–400mg: a little under 50% of studies (9/21) show no effect, 12/21 show significant increases
>400mg: bad
Caffeine activates (thereby overstimulating) midbrain periacqueductal gray matter

2017: forts rich in say fats and fructose increase anxiety-like behaviors in rats
Lower calorie diet in mice <-> decrease anxiety, improve blood flow
2016 — Sophie — rats on high fat diet more prone to diabetes and anxiety

Foods to keep out of your diet:
Western diet
Bad fats (saturated, trans, PUFAs like vegetable oil used for deep frying), high GI carbs (fried foods, sweetened (esp with HFCS) drinks, and lots of red meat
Norwegian diet: canola oil instead of olive oil
Review these next three minutes. Depression-fighting foods cheat sheet:
Wait, what choices did he make during the day that led to his no longer craving ice cream or cookies at night?

Oregano (carvacrol) in animals helps against depression
Used to marinate olives and feta cheese
Eaten on oven-roasted vegetable

Turmeric (2% curcumin by weight = 136 mg per teaspoon turmeric)
Effective dose against depression 500mg—1g curcumin = 5–10 teaspoons of turmeric per day

Or use less, and use it with black pepper, because piperine increases curcumin absorption by 2,000%

Saffron reduces depression symptoms
15 mg of saffron is like 20 mg of Prozac
We don’t know it’s mechanism of action (MOA)
Increases glutamate and dopamine
More expensive than gold per pound
Strong taste

Spices: antioxidant properties (fighting off free radicals, preventing oxidative stress)* look up the mechanism again
Antidepressant

Selenium improves mood scores
Brazil (?) nuts

Zinc sources:
Seafood (esp. cooked oysters), lean beef, poultry. Also a bit in beans/nuts/whole grains
Zinc -> lower brain inflammation -> lower risk of depression / depressive symptoms

Potassium improves mood, but not as clear
Sweet potatoes, bananas, mushrooms, oranges, peas, cucumbers

Magnesium sources:
Avocados, nuts, seeds, legumes whole grains, omega-3 rich fish (salmon, mackerel)
Magnesium deficiency -> major depression

Iron sources:
Shellfish, lean red meats & organ meats (in moderation), legumes, pumpkin seeds, broccoli, dark chocolate (sweet? in moderation)
Iron: covering that protects neurons, controls synthesis of mood chemicals/pathway, large amount of iron in basal ganglia (BG)
Vitamin C: citrus, cantaloupe, strawberries, broccoli/cauliflower/Brussels sprouts
Vitamin C: regulation of NT synthesis

Vitamin A foods
Sweet potatoes, carrots, spinach, black-eyed peas

In MS patients, vitamin A can improve fatigue & depression.
But too much (more than you get from foods) vitamin A-derived retinoic acid has the opposite effect

B1/B6 mood regulation 
Vitamin A helps with e.g. elongation and adaptation (specialization?) of neutrons

⬆️ Folate -> more hippocampal cells (better memory to cope w/ depression and less depression)
And
Folate appears to help w/ serotonin synthesis
B12 deficiency -> Folate (B9) deficiency -> loss of (esp. hippocampal) brain cells (ie hippocampal atrophy) -> depression
Replace plain vegetable oil w/ canola oil. Healthier; low omega-6:3 ratio = 2:1

Omega-6 to Omega-3
American diet: 15:1
Ideal ratio: 4:1

Cut down on (O6) full-fat cheese, high-fat cuts of red meat, corn oil, palm oil
Eat more fatty fish (spec. Cold-water fatty fish: salmon/mackerel/tuna/herring/sardines is better than bass/tilapia/cod/shellfish, walnuts, vegetable oil, dark,leafy vegetables

Farmed fish usually more O3 than wild fish. Fish eat phytoplankton eats micro algae

Grass-fed beef > commercial beef
Alphalinolenic acid in edamame, walnuts, chia seeds
We have too many omega-6s, so we need more omega-3’s to even out the 6/3 balance for our bodies. This is found well in fish
Nitrates (preservative, and color): If you have to eat them (salami/sausages), try to find meats with buckwheat flour as a filler, which has antioxidants
Corn/sunflower/safflower oil in moderation may be ok. In excess, they cause an imbalance in omega-3/omega-6 fatty acids (FAs), impacting emotional regulation -> depression

Trans-fats linked to depression. Olive oil is good. MUFAs should make up the majority of fats in your diet. MUFAs: olive oil, nuts (almonds, walnuts), nut butters (almond/cashew butter), avocados
Mono-/poly unsaturated fats (MUFA/PUFA) negatively correlated with depression. Trans fats are banned by the FDA, but there’s a transition period.
Japanese study: reduce fried food consumption -> reduce lifetime depression incidence
Myloperoxidase -> depression
Aspartame and sucrose may be causing/worsening depression
Review: probiotics break down prebiotics
Grapefruit interacts with many drugs/meds
Serotonin deficient if depressed or anxious. [which is why I need sleep]
Vagus nerve: CNS to gut. Then after penetrating gut wall, it spreads out into many nerves
100m-500m neutral crest cells of CNS also form the enteric NS
Woah. I just deleted E7 from my Bluetooth devices, and marked these WH-CH700Ns as Device Type: Headphones, and they got way louder right away. Perfect, problem fixed.
